Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

The writer and zoologist Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies. Why are the feet and legs such accurate reflectors of our sentiments? For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed by either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times.

The transition from an oral culture, in which knowledge was handed down through stories, songs, and apprenticeships, to a literate one, based on the written word, was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material. Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport. Wood suffers from splitting and is susceptible to decay. Wall paintings are static and space is limited. The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese, solved these problems, but it wasn't until the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex — or, as we call it now, the book — that the material reached its full potential. That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word. That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the guardian of the written word is a remarkable materials story.

A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim. No matter how we might state it in shorthand, it is, analytically, a complex interaction of many ideas and implications. The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises. For example, the claim that 'university education should be free for all Australians' might be supported by the reason that 'the economy benefits from a well-educated Australian population'. But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly. The conclusion is about universities and free education, while the reason introduces some new ideas: economic benefit and a well-educated population. While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas in the initial statement of our reason.

The word "migration" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntary—people fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines long-term outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

annotations.text: 밑줄 친 our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The writer and zoologist Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies. Why are the feet and legs such accurate reflectors of our sentiments? For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed by either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, <u>our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times</u>.

annotations.html: 밑줄 친 guardian of the written word가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 밑줄 친 guardian of the written word가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The transition from an oral culture, in which knowledge was handed down through stories, songs, and apprenticeships, to a literate one, based on the written word, was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material. Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport. Wood suffers from splitting and is susceptible to decay. Wall paintings are static and space is limited. The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese, solved these problems, but it wasn't until the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex — or, as we call it now, the book — that the material reached its full potential. That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word. That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the <u>guardian of the written word</u> is a remarkable materials story.

annotations.html: 밑줄 친 the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 밑줄 친 the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim. No matter how we might state it in shorthand, it is, analytically, a complex interaction of many ideas and implications. The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises. For example, the claim that 'university education should be free for all Australians' might be supported by the reason that 'the economy benefits from a well-educated Australian population'. But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly. The conclusion is about universities and free education, while the reason introduces some new ideas: economic benefit and a well-educated population. While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, <u>the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas</u> in the initial statement of our reason.

annotations.html: 밑줄 친 migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 밑줄 친 migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The word "migration" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntary—people fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But <u>migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems</u>. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines long-term outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

annotations.html: 밑줄 친 This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?
annotations.text: 밑줄 친 This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. <u>This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money</u>, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

annotations.text: 밑줄 친 when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making가 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that <u>when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making</u>. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

To determine the mass of my bowling ball, I might put it onto a balance and compare it with a known mass, such as a number of metal cubes each weighing 1,10 , or 100 grams. Things get much more complicated if want to know the mass of a distant star. How do I measure it? We can roughly say that measuring the mass of a star involves various theories. If we want to measure the mass of a binary star, we first determine a center of mass between the two stars, then their distance from that center which we can then use, together with a value for the period and a certain instance of Kepler's Third Law, to calculate the mass. In other words, in order to "measure" the star mass, we measure other quantities and use those values, together with certain equations, to calculate the mass. Measurement is not a simple and unmediated estimation of independently existing properties, but a determination of certain magnitudes before the background of a number of accepted theories.

To determine the mass of my bowling ball, I might put it onto a balance and compare it with a known mass, such as a number of metal cubes each weighing 1, 10, or 100 grams. Things get much more complicated if I want to know the mass of a distant star. How do I measure it? We can roughly say that measuring the mass of a star involves various theories. If we want to measure the mass of a binary star, we first determine a center of mass between the two stars, then their distance from that center which we can then use, together with a value for the period and a certain instance of Kepler's Third Law, to calculate the mass. In other words, in order to "measure" the star mass, we measure other quantities and use those values, together with certain equations, to calculate the mass. Measurement is not a simple and unmediated estimation of independently existing properties, but a determination of certain magnitudes before the background of a number of accepted theories.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

④ Aristotle's philosophical contributions to modern understanding of neurological sensory processing
⑤ The historical development of scientific understanding about brain functions and sensory perception

The writer and zoologist Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies. Why are the feet and legs such accurate reflectors of our sentiments? For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed by either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times.

① The unconscious limbic brain responses that trigger movement in dangerous environments
② Why feet and legs honestly reflect our thoughts and feelings through evolutionary hardwiring
③ How ancestral survival responses influence modern human behavior in threatening situations
④ The evolutionary development of human feet and legs as survival mechanisms
⑤ Desmond Morris's research on the relationship between human emotions and physical reactions

The transition from an oral culture, in which knowledge was handed down through stories, songs, and apprenticeships, to a literate one, based on the written word, was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material. Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport. Wood suffers from splitting and is susceptible to decay. Wall paintings are static and space is limited. The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese, solved these problems, but it wasn't until the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex — or, as we call it now, the book — that the material reached its full potential. That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word. That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the guardian of the written word is a remarkable materials story.

① The evolution of human knowledge transfer from oral traditions to written records
② The limitations of ancient writing materials before the invention of paper
③ Paper's remarkable triumph as the ideal writing material in human civilization
④ The historical challenges in preserving knowledge through different recording methods
⑤ How Roman innovation of the codex revolutionized written communication worldwide

A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim. No matter how we might state it in shorthand, it is, analytically, a complex interaction of many ideas and implications. The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises. For example, the claim that 'university education should be free for all Australians' might be supported by the reason that 'the economy benefits from a welleducated Australian population'. But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly. The conclusion is about universities and free education, while the reason introduces some new ideas: economic benefit and a well-educated population. While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas in the initial statement of our reason.

annotations.html:
① How to construct effective arguments by linking premises to desired conclusions
② Analyzing the relationship between education policies and economic benefits in Australia
③ The importance of providing free university education to stimulate economic growth
④ Why obvious connections between ideas should be challenged in academic discourse
⑤ The necessity of breaking down reasoning into precise premises rather than single claims

The word "migration" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntary—people fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines longterm outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

annotations.html:
① The economic challenges faced by migrants in overcrowded labor markets worldwide
② The complex reality of migration as both a challenge and solution to socioeconomic issues
③ Long-term positive effects of migration on both origin and destination communities
④ The misconception of migration as a crisis in media and scientific publications
⑤ Demographic characteristics of migrants who leave their homelands seeking better opportunities

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

annotations.html:
① The historical evolution of gold-backed currency systems throughout different civilizations
② The economic and social consequences of inflation caused by government spending
③ The function of gold as a constraint on government's ability to create inflationary money
④ How governments throughout history have manipulated currency for political advantage
⑤ The misleading nature of expressions about paper money being backed by precious metals

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

The word "__________" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntarypeople fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines longterm outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that __________ to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be __________ for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines long-term outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of __________ to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self-destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

The writer and zoologist Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies. Why are the feet and legs such accurate reflectors of our sentiments? For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed by either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times.

For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed by either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times.

① When faced with something disagreeable, our feet and legs may react similarly to how they did in prehistoric times.
② Our ancestral survival mechanisms related to foot and leg movements continue to serve us today.
③ The limbic brain has evolved significantly, making our leg reactions different from prehistoric times.
④ Feet and legs react instantaneously to environmental threats without conscious thought.
⑤ According to Desmond Morris, feet are the most honest communicators of our thoughts and feelings.

The transition from an oral culture, in which knowledge was handed down through stories, songs, and apprenticeships, to a literate one, based on the written word, was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material. Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport. Wood suffers from splitting and is susceptible to decay. Wall paintings are static and space is limited. The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese, solved these problems, but it wasn't until the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex — or, as we call it now, the book — that the material reached its full potential. That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word. That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the guardian of the written word is a remarkable materials story.

⑤ Stone and clay tablets were difficult to transport due to their weight and bulkiness.

A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim. No matter how we might state it in shorthand, it is, analytically, a complex interaction of many ideas and implications. The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises. For example, the claim that 'university education should be free for all Australians' might be supported by the reason that 'the economy benefits from a welleducated Australian population'. But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly. The conclusion is about universities and free education, while the reason introduces some new ideas: economic benefit and a well-educated population. While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas in the initial statement of our reason.

The word "migration" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntary—people fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines longterm outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

annotations.html:
① Migration is often portrayed as causing problems such as urban overcrowding.
② Many migrants move to seek better economic opportunities.
③ Research shows migration typically has negative long-term effects on both origin and destination places.
④ Migration tends to attract younger and healthier individuals who are willing to face challenges.
⑤ Migration can help redistribute workers from areas with labor surplus to places with higher demand.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

① The expression "backed up by gold" means the value of gold is transferred to paper money.
② Throughout history, both ancient kings and modern politicians have yielded to the temptation to create more money.
③ Many countries have used materials with limited supply as money to prevent government-driven inflation.
④ Gold is considered ideal for backing currency because its supply cannot be increased rapidly.
⑤ Government-created money often leads to inflation when officials create too much of it.

⑤ Government-created money often leads to inflation when officials create too much of it.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

annotations.html:
① Good decisions result from cooperation between emotional and deliberative parts of the brain.
② Conventional economics suggests that emotions enhance the quality of decision-making processes.
③ Research evidence indicates that emotions often play a positive role in decision making.
④ Antonio Damasio's research shows that damage to the emotional part of the brain reduces decision-making effectiveness.
⑤ Neuroscience tools are used to study emotions and decision making.
annotations.text:
① Good decisions result from cooperation between emotional and deliberative parts of the brain.
② Conventional economics suggests that emotions enhance the quality of decision-making processes.
③ Research evidence indicates that emotions often play a positive role in decision making.
④ Antonio Damasio's research shows that damage to the emotional part of the brain reduces decision-making effectiveness.
⑤ Neuroscience tools are used to study emotions and decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

③ Turtles have recently changed their behavior to adapt to modern beach developments.
④ Baby turtles crawl toward the light because they have poor eyesight.
⑤ Following the brightest lights is now leading baby turtles into dangerous situations.

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind-folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect.

① Modern science has disproven Aristotle's theories about sensory perception.
② The brain can directly sense light and touch without using sensory organs.
③ People placed in sensory deprivation tanks experience hallucinations and disordered thinking.
④ Aristotle was the first scientist to conduct sensory deprivation experiments.
⑤ Patients are always unconscious during brain surgery to avoid pain.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be <u>backed up</u> by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

annotations.text: 밑줄 친 This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. 이(가) 다음 글에서 의미하는 바로 가장 적절한 것은?

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. <u>This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process</u>. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles heading for the brightest nearby lights were being guided straight into traffic. Are self- destructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights.

annotations.text: 다음 글을 읽고, 주제문을 주어진 조건에 맞게 완성하시오.

A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim. No matter how we might state it in shorthand, it is, analytically, a complex interaction of many ideas and implications. The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises. For example, the claim that 'university education should be free for all Australians' might be supported by the reason that 'the economy benefits from a welleducated Australian population'. But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly. The conclusion is about universities and free education, while the reason introduces some new ideas: economic benefit and a well-educated population. While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections between the various ideas in the initial statement of our reason.

annotations.text: 다음 글을 읽고, 주제문을 주어진 조건에 맞게 완성하시오.

The word "migration" is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis. For example, migrants are assumed to overcrowd cities, clog up labor markets, and increase poverty. The other questionable assumption is that most migration is involuntary—people fleeing natural or man-made disasters. The reality, however, is more complex, and many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity. Of course migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems. For example, out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity. Migration is generally selective of persons who are younger, healthier, more flexible, and more willing to endure hardship in hopes of a better life relative to their prospects in their places of origin. Most research that examines long-term outcomes of migration, including remittances and intergenerational mobility, finds positive "long-term" effects on places of origin and destination.

annotations.text: 다음 글을 읽고, 주제문을 주어진 조건에 맞게 완성하시오.

The big problem with money created by the government is that those who run the government always face the temptation to create more money and spend it. Whether among ancient kings or modern politicians, this has happened again and again over the centuries, leading to inflation and the many economic and social problems that follow from inflation. For this reason, many countries have preferred using gold, silver, or some other material that is inherently limited in supply, as money. It is a way of depriving governments of the power to expand the money supply to inflationary levels. Gold has long been considered ideal for this purpose, since the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly. When paper money is convertible into gold whenever the individual chooses to do so, then the money is said to be "backed up" by gold. This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued.

annotations.text: 다음 글을 읽고, 주제문을 주어진 조건에 맞게 완성하시오.

The study of emotions and decision making is now of considerable importance. This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience. One important stream of the literature examines people with brain damage and how damage to particular parts of the brain known to be responsible for particular cognitive functions impacts on decision making. One example of this research is the work of Antonio Damasio, who finds that when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making. Good decisions are a product of the emotional part of the brain working in conjunction with the deliberative part. This contradicts the assumptions of conventional economics, where emotions play a negative role in the decision-making process. Here it is assumed that decision making can be modeled as being generated in a stoic, unemotional fashion, and that's why decisions tend to be optimal. But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making.

Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light. For millions of years this was a highly rational and effective strategy because the light on a dark beach represented the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface. Following the lights led baby turtles back home to the sea. The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels on the other side of the beach. Now after hatching, turtles __________ straight into traffic. Are selfdestructive sea turtles naturally irrational? Yes, in the modern world. But there's a deeper truth. Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision-making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights

Sensory organs are the only channels of communication between the brain and the outside world. Simply put, the brain is not designed to sense on its own. For instance, an exposed brain would neither sense light shining on it nor feel something touching it. In fact, patients are often kept awake during brain surgery, which can help a surgeon isolate specific regions of the brain. The ancient Greek philosopher Aristotle recognized this characteristic of the brain over 2,000 years ago when he said, "Nothing is in the mind __________." This concept can be seen clearly when volunteers are blind -folded and placed in the warm water of a sensory deprivation tank. They soon experience visual, auditory, and tactile (touch) hallucinations, as well as incoherent thought patterns. From these experiments and others, it is apparent that we need constant input from our senses to carry out functions that give us personality and intellect

The writer and zoologist Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies. Why are the feet and legs such accurate reflectors of our sentiments? For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats (e.g., hot sand, ill- tempered lions) instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought. Our limbic brains made sure that __________ ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat. This survival regimen, retained from our ancestral heritage, has served us well and continues to do so today. In fact, these ageold reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times

The transition from an oral culture, in which knowledge was handed down through stories, songs, and apprenticeships, to a literate one, based on the written word, was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material. Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport. Wood suffers from splitting and is susceptible to decay. Wall paintings are static and space is limited. The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese, solved these problems, but it wasn't until the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex — or, __________ — that the material reached its full potential. That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word. That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the guardian of the written word is a remarkable materials story

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 바다거북 새끼들이 수백만 년 동안 빛을 향해 기어가는 진화적 전략을 발달시켰으며, 이는 달과 별빛이 수면에 반사되는 자연 환경에서는 합리적이었으나 인간이 해변가에 집과 호텔을 지으면서 문제가 발생했다고 설명한다. 글의 핵심은 "Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision‐making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights"라는 문장에 드러나 있으며, 이는 진화된 메커니즘이 현대 환경과 충돌할 때 발생하는 딜레마를 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 바다거북이 자신들의 조상에게는 합리적이었던 빛을 향해 이동하는 본능이 현대의 인공 조명으로 인해 혼란에 빠지게 되었다는 의미이다. 본문에서 설명하듯이 바다거북은 수백만 년 동안 달빛과 별빛이 바다 표면에 반사된 빛을 따라 바다로 돌아가는 전략을 발전시켰지만, 인간이 해변가에 집과 호텔을 지으면서 가장 밝은 빛을 따라가는 거북들이 오히려 위험한 방향으로 이끌리게 되었다. 따라서 "blinded by modern lights"는 인공 광원이 거북이의 자연적인 항해 체계를 방해하여 혼란을 일으킨다는 의미이다

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 아리스토텔레스가 2,000년 전에 인식한 뇌의 특성을 나타내는 것으로, 모든 인간의 지식이 감각적 경험을 통해서만 얻어진다는 의미이다. 본문에서는 뇌가 스스로 감각할 수 없으며 감각 기관이 뇌와 외부 세계 사이의 유일한 소통 채널이라고 설명하고 있다. 또한 감각 차단 실험에서 자원자들이 환각과 비논리적 사고 패턴을 경험한다는 사실을 통해, 우리의 인격과 지성을 구성하는 기능을 수행하기 위해서는 감각으로부터의 지속적인 입력이 필요하다는 점을 강조하고 있다. 따라서 "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses"는 모든 인간의 지식이 전적으로 감각적 인식에서 비롯된다는 의미이다.
annotations.text: 해설: 이 구절은 아리스토텔레스가 2,000년 전에 인식한 뇌의 특성을 나타내는 것으로, 모든 인간의 지식이 감각적 경험을 통해서만 얻어진다는 의미이다. 본문에서는 뇌가 스스로 감각할 수 없으며 감각 기관이 뇌와 외부 세계 사이의 유일한 소통 채널이라고 설명하고 있다. 또한 감각 차단 실험에서 자원자들이 환각과 비논리적 사고 패턴을 경험한다는 사실을 통해, 우리의 인격과 지성을 구성하는 기능을 수행하기 위해서는 감각으로부터의 지속적인 입력이 필요하다는 점을 강조하고 있다. 따라서 "Nothing is in the mind that does not pass through the senses"는 모든 인간의 지식이 전적으로 감각적 인식에서 비롯된다는 의미이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 위험하거나 불쾌한 상황에 직면했을 때 우리의 발과 다리가 선사시대와 마찬가지로 무의식적으로 반응한다는 의미이다. 본문의 앞부분에서 데즈먼드 모리스가 "발이 우리의 생각과 감정을 다른 어떤 신체 부위보다 정직하게 전달한다"고 언급했으며, 이러한 반응이 "의식적인 생각 없이 즉각적으로" 일어난다고 설명하고 있다. 따라서 밑줄 친 부분은 우리의 무의식적인 발과 다리의 움직임이 우리의 진정한 감정과 생각을 드러낸다는 의미를 가장 적절하게 표현하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에서 "guardian of the written word"는 문자로 된 지식을 보존하고 전달하는 매체로서의 종이를 비유적으로 표현한 것이다. 글의 맥락에서 종이가 돌이나 나무와 같은 다른 재료들과 비교되며 이들의 단점을 극복하고 문자 기록의 주요 매체로 자리 잡았음을 설명하고 있다. 특히 종이가 코덱스(책)의 형태로 발전하면서 "full potential"에 도달했다고 언급하며, 종이가 역사적 문서를 기록하는 데 선호되는 표면으로서 문자 지식의 보존자 역할을 하게 되었음을 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 추론의 목적이 '명백해 보이는' 연결성을 가정하는 대신 다양한 아이디어 간의 연결을 신중하게 검토하는 것이라고 설명한다. 본문은 결론과 이유 사이의 관계가 표면적으로 명백해 보일지라도, 실제로는 여러 아이디어 간의 복잡한 상호작용을 분석해야 한다고 강조한다. 이는 비판적 사고가 겉보기에 자명해 보이는 연결성을 무비판적으로 수용하지 않고 철저히 검증해야 한다는 의미이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 이주가 단순히 문제나 위기가 아니라 기존에 존재하던 문제들의 해결책이 될 수 있다는 의미이다. 본문에서는 이에 대한 예시로 "out-migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity"라고 설명하며, 이주가 노동력 과잉 지역에서 수요가 더 많거나 기회가 더 많은 지역으로 노동자를 재분배한다고 언급하고 있다. 또한 본문은 이주의 장기적 결과가 출발지와 목적지 모두에 긍정적인 영향을 미친다고 설명하고 있다. 따라서 이 구절은 인간의 이동성이 기존의 경제적 불균형과 노동력 분배 문제를 해결할 수 있음을 의미한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 구절은 "돈이 금에 의해 뒷받침된다"는 표현이 금의 가치가 종이 화폐로 전이된다고 상상할 때만 오해의 소지가 있다는 의미이다. 본문은 이어서 실제 요점은 금이 단순히 발행될 수 있는 종이 화폐의 양을 제한한다는 것이라고 설명한다. 따라서 밑줄 친 표현은 금의 가치가 직접적으로 종이 화폐에 통합된다는 오해를 가리키며, 실제로는 금본위제의 주요 기능이 통화 공급을 제한하는 것임을 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 글쓴이는 발과 다리가 수백만 년 동안 위협에 대해 즉각적으로 반응해 왔으며, 이러한 생존 메커니즘이 선조로부터 물려받은 것이라고 설명한다. 또한 이러한 반응이 오늘날까지도 우리에게 잘 작동하고 있으며, 위험하거나 불쾌한 것에 직면했을 때 여전히 선사시대와 같은 방식으로 반응한다고 강조한다. 따라서 발과 다리가 선조로부터 물려받은 생존 반응을 현대에도 여전히 보여준다는 것이 글의 요지이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 구전 문화에서 문자 문화로의 전환 과정에서 적합한 필기 재료의 부재로 인한 어려움을 설명하고, 종이의 발명이 이러한 문제들을 해결했으며, 로마인들이 두루마리를 코덱스(책)로 대체했을 때 종이의 잠재력이 완전히 발휘되었다고 설명한다. 마지막 문장에서 "종이가 문자의 수호자로서 승리한 것은 주목할 만한 재료 이야기"라고 강조하며 글의 요지를 드러내고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 결론을 뒷받침하는 이유가 단일 주장으로 구성되기 어렵다고 설명한다. 글에서는 이유가 분석적으로 여러 아이디어와 함축의 복잡한 상호작용이므로 더 정확한 전제들의 연쇄로 분석되어야 한다고 주장한다. 호주 대학교육 무상화 예시를 통해 단일 진술만으로는 상황을 명확히 분석할 수 없으며, 추론의 목적은 '명백한' 것을 가정하지 않고 초기 이유 진술에 있는 다양한 아이디어 간의 연결을 신중하게 검토하는 것임을 강조한다.

annotations.html: 글에서는 이주가 대중 매체나 과학 문헌에서 문제나 위기로 보도되지만, 실제로는 이주가 사회적, 경제적 문제를 일으킬 수도 있으나 동시에 기존 문제의 해결책이 될 수도 있다고 설명한다. 노동력 재분배, 젊고 건강한 인력의 이동, 송금과 세대 간 이동성 등을 통해 출발지와 목적지 모두에 장기적으로 긍정적인 영향을 미칠 수 있다는 점을 강조하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 정부가 발행하는 화폐의 문제점은 정부가 더 많은 돈을 만들고 지출하려는 유혹에 직면한다는 것이다. 이러한 행위는 인플레이션과 여러 경제적, 사회적 문제를 초래한다. 따라서 많은 국가들이 금과 같이 공급이 제한된 물질을 화폐로 사용하는 것을 선호해왔다. 금본위제는 정부가 통화량을 인플레이션 수준으로 확대하는 것을 제한하는 방법이며, 이것이 글의 핵심 요지이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에서는 Antonio Damasio의 연구를 통해 뇌의 감정 부분이 손상되면 의사결정 효율성이 감소한다는 사실을 제시하고 있다. 좋은 결정은 뇌의 감정적 부분과 숙고적 부분이 함께 작용할 때 이루어지며, 이는 감정이 의사결정 과정에서 부정적 역할을 한다고 가정하는 전통 경제학의 관점과 대조된다. 결국 감정은 의사결정에서 중요하고 긍정적인 역할을 한다는 것이 글의 핵심이다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문은 감정이 의사 결정에서 부정적인 역할을 한다는 전통적인 경제학 가정과 달리, 실제로는 긍정적인 역할을 한다는 것을 강조하고 있다. 특히 다마시오의 연구를 통해 감정적 부분이 손상된 뇌는 의사 결정 효율성이 감소한다는 증거를 제시하며, 좋은 결정은 감정적 부분과 숙고적 부분이 함께 작용한 결과임을 설명한다. 다른 선택지들은 본문의 일부 내용만 다루거나 주요 논점을 완전히 포괄하지 못한다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 바다거북 새끼들이 수백만 년 동안 빛을 향해 기어가는 진화적 전략을 발달시켰으며, 이는 달과 별빛이 수면에 반사되는 자연 환경에서는 합리적이었으나 인간이 해변가에 집과 호텔을 지으면서 문제가 발생했다고 설명한다. 글의 핵심은 "Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision‐making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights"라는 문장에 드러나 있으며, 이는 진화된 메커니즘이 현대 환경과 충돌할 때 발생하는 딜레마를 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 뇌와 외부 세계 사이의 유일한 소통 통로로서 감각 기관의 중요성을 설명하고 있다. 글에서는 "감각 기관 은 뇌와 외부 세계 사이의 유일한 소통 통로"라고 명시하 며, 노출된 뇌는 빛이나 접촉을 직접 감지할 수 없다는 예시를 제공한다. 또한 아리스토텔레스의 "감각을 통하지 않고 마음에 들어오는 것은 없다"는 말과 감각 차단 실험에서 환각과 비논리적 사고 패턴이 나타난다는 사실을 통해, 우 리의 성격과 지성을 구성하는 기능을 수행하기 위해서는 감각으로부터의 지속적인 입력이 필요하다는 결론에 도달한 다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 발과 다리가 우리의 생각과 감정을 가장 정직하게 전달한다는 Desmond Morris의 관찰로 시작하여, 왜 발과 다리가 우리 감정의 정확한 반영체인지 설명하고 있다. 수백만 년 동안 인간이 말을 하기 훨씬 전부터 우리의 다리와 발은 의식적인 생각 없이 환경적 위협에 즉각적으로 반응했으며, 이러한 생존 체제는 조상으로부터 물려받은 유산으로 오늘날까지 우리에게 잘 작용하고 있다고 설명한다. 따라서 우리의 발과 다리가 왜 진정한 감정을 드러내는지에 대한 이유를 설명하는 글로, 제목으로는 "Why Our Feet and Legs Reveal Our True Feelings"가 가장 적절하다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 구두 문화에서 문자 문화로의 전환이 적합한 필기 재료의 부족으로 수세기 동안 지연되었다는 내용으로 시작하여 돌, 점토, 나무, 벽화 등 다양한 필기 재료의 한계점을 설명한다. 중국의 4대 발명품 중 하나인 종이의 발명이 이러한 문제들을 해결했으며, 로마인들이 두루마리를 책(codex)으로 대체했을 때 종이가 그 잠재력을 완전히 발휘했다고 서술한다. 글의 마지막 문장 "That paper, a much softer material than either stone or wood, won out as the guardian of the written word is a remarkable materials story"에서 글의 핵심 주제가 종이라는 놀라운 재료가 문자 문화를 혁명적으로 변화시켰다는 것임을 명확히 보여준다.

annotations.html: 해설: 이 글은 정부가 발행하는 화폐의 문제점과 금과 같은 공급이 제한된 물질을 화폐로 사용하는 이유를 설명한다. 글에 따르면 정부는 항상 더 많은 돈을 만들고 지출하려는 유혹에 직면하며, 이는 인플레이션으로 이어진다. 따라서 많은 국가들이 금이나 은과 같이 공급이 제한된 물질을 화폐로 사용하는 것을 선호했는데, 이는 정부가 화폐 공급을 인플레이션 수준으로 확대할 수 있는 권한을 박탈하는 방법이다. 이어지는 내용에서도 금의 공급이 급격히 증가할 수 없기 때문에 이러한 목적에 이상적이라고 설명하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 지문에서 Desmond Morris가 관찰한 바에 따르면 우리의 발은 생각과 감정(what we think and feel)을 정직하게 전달한다고 언급함. 특히 발과 다리가 수백만 년 동안 의식적 사고 없이 즉각적으로(instantaneously, without the need for conscious thought) 환경적 위협에 반응해왔다는 점을 강조함. 이러한 생존 메커니즘은 우리의 조상으로부터 물려받은 것으로, 오늘날까지도 위험하거나 불쾌한 것에 직면했을 때 선사시대와 같은 방식으로 반응한다고 설명함.

annotations.html:
1. True. 해설: 새끼 거북이들은 빛을 향해 기어가도록 진화했다. 텍스트에서 "Turtle hatchlings have, it seems, evolved to crawl toward the light."라고 명시되어 있으며, 이것이 수백만 년 동안 효과적인 생존 전략이었다고 설명한다.
2. False. 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 역사적으로 해변의 빛은 인공적인 광원이 아니라 "the reflection of the moon and stars on the water's surface"(물 표면에 반사된 달과 별빛)에서 왔다.
3. True. 해설: 텍스트는 "The problems started when humans began building beachfront homes and sparkling hotels"라고 명시하며, 이로 인해 거북이들이 바다 대신 교통량이 많은 곳으로 인도되고 있다고 설명한 다.
4. False. 해설: 텍스트는 거북이들이 본질적으로 비합리적이라고 주장하지 않는다. 오히려 "Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors"라고 설명하며, 현대 세계에서만 그들의 행동이 비합리적으로 보인다고 한다.
5. True. 해설: 텍스트에서 명확히 "Turtles are basing their decisions on simple cues that were perfectly rational for their ancestors; these days, however, their evolved decision‐making mechanisms are being blinded by modern lights."라고 언급하고 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트 첫 문장에서 "Desmond Morris observed that our feet communicate exactly what we think and feel more honestly than any other part of our bodies"라고 명시하고 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 "For millions of years, long before humans spoke, our legs and feet reacted to environmental threats"라고 언급되어 있어, 발과 다리의 반응은 언어 발달 이전에 이미 존재했다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에서 "Our limbic brains made sure that our feet and legs reacted as needed"라고 언급하여 변연계 뇌(limbic brain)가 발과 다리의 반응을 담당한다고 설명하고 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 위협에 대한 발과 다리의 반응은 "either ceasing motion, running away, or kicking at a potential threat"라는 세 가지 방식으로 나타난다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트 마지막 문장에서 "these age-old reactions are still so hardwired in us that when we are presented with something dangerous or even disagreeable, our feet and legs still react as they did in prehistoric times"라고 언급하여 현대 인간도 여전히 선사시대와 같은 반응을 보인다고 설명하고 있다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, "The transition from an oral culture... to a literate one... was held back for centuries by the lack of suitable writing material."라고 명시되어 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "Stone and clay tablets were used, but they were prone to fracture and were bulky and heavy to transport."라고 언급하고 있어, 이상적인 재료가 아니었음을 보여준다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에서 "The invention of paper, said to be one of the four great inventions of the Chinese"라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 로마인들은 종이를 발명한 것이 아니라 "the Romans replaced the scroll with the codex - or, as we call it now, the book"라고 설명하고 있다. 종이는 중국의 발명품이다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트에서 "That was two thousand years ago, and it is still a dominant form of the written word."라고 명시하고 있어, 책 형태가 약 2000년 동안 주요 형태로 사용되어 왔음을 보여준다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "A reason for a conclusion is very unlikely to consist in a single claim"이라고 명확히 언급하고 있다. 결론을 뒷받침하는 이유는 단일 주장으로 구성되기 어렵다고 설명한다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서 "The reason must be broken down into a chain of more precise premises"라고 명시하고 있다. 이유는 더 정확한 전제들의 연쇄로 분해되어야 한다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면, 이 두 개념 사이의 연결은 명확하게 표현되지 않았다. "But is our analysis of the situation clearly expressed in just one statement? Hardly."라고 설명하며, 이 연결이 추가 분석을 필요로 함을 시사한다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트는 "the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious' by carefully working through the connections"라고 명시하고 있다. 추론의 목적은 '명백한' 것을 가정하는 것이 아니라 연결성을 신중하게 검토하는 것이다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트는 "While the link between these two ideas and the conclusion might seem obvious, the purpose of reasoning is to avoid assuming the 'obvious'"라고 언급하며, 이 연결이 신중한 분석을 필요로 함을 시사한다. 따라서 "잘 교육된 인구"와 "무료 대학 교육 " 사이의 연결은 신중한 분석이 필요하다.

annotations.html:
(1) 해설: 텍스트의 첫 문장에서 "The word 'migration' is almost always reported in the popular media and even in scientific literature as a problem or a crisis"라고 명시하고 있다.
(2) 해설: 텍스트에서는 이것이 "questionable assumption"(의심스러운 가정)이라고 설명하며, "many migrants are simply seeking greater economic opportunity"(많은 이주자들은 단순히 더 나은 경제적 기회를 찾고 있다)라고 반박하고 있다.
(3) 해설: 텍스트에 따르면 "migration can and does create social and economic problems. But migration can also be a solution for many preexisting problems"라고 설명하며 이주가 문제를 만들 수 있지만 동시에 기존 문제에 대한 해결책이 될 수도 있다고 언급한다.
(4) 해설: 텍스트에서 "out‐migration generally redistributes workers from places of labor surplus to areas where there is greater demand or more opportunity"라고 명확히 언급하고 있다.
(5) 해설: 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "Most research that examines long‐term outcomes of migration... finds positive 'long-term' effects on places of origin and destination"라고 언급하며 이주가 출발지와 도착지 모두에 긍정적인 장기적 효과를 가져온다고 설명한다.

(3) 금은 세계의 공급량이 빠르게 증가할 수 없기 때문에 이상적인 것으로 간주되어 왔다. 텍스트에서 "the supply of gold in the world usually cannot be increased rapidly"라고 설명되어 있다.
(4) 텍스트에 따르면, "This expression is misleading only if we imagine that the value of the gold is somehow transferred to the paper money, when in fact the real point is that the gold simply limits the amount of paper money that can be issued."라고 명시되어 있다.

(1) 텍스트의 첫 부분에서 "This involves the application of various tools afforded by neuroscience"라고 명시하고 있어, 신경과학 도구가 감정과 의사결정 연구에 관련이 있음을 보여준다.
(2) 텍스트에 따르면, "when the emotional part of the brain is damaged, this actually reduces the efficacy of decision making"라고 언급되어 있어, 감정을 담당하는 뇌 부위의 손상이 의사결정 효율성을 감소시킨다고 설명한다.

(5) 텍스트의 마지막 문장에서 "But the evidence suggests that emotions actually play an important and, often, a positive role in decision making"라고 명시하고 있다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에서는 벽화(wall paintings)가 종이 발명 이후 선호되는 기록 매체가 되었다는 내용을 언급하지 않았습니다. 오히려 벽화는 고정적이고 공간이 제한적이라는 단점이 있다고 설명하고 있으며, 종이의 발명이 이러한 문제들을 해결했다고 언급하고 있습니다. 나머지 보기들은 본문 내용과 일치합니다. 석재와 점토 타블렛은 무겁고 부피가 커서 운반이 어려웠고, 로마인들이 스크롤을 코덱스(책)로 대체하면서 문자 기록 매체가 잠재력을 발휘했으며, 종이는 중국의 4대 발명품 중 하나로 언급되었고, 책 형태는 2천 년 전에 확립되어 오늘날까지도 문자의 지배적인 형태로 남아있다는 내용이 본문에 제시되어 있습니다.

annotations.html: 해설: 본문에서는 "backed up by gold"라는 표현이 "금의 가치가 지폐로 이전된다"는 의미로 이해하는 것은 오해라고 명시하고 있다. 실제로는 금이 발행할 수 있는 지폐의 양을 제한하는 역할을 한다고 설명한다. 반면 다른 보기들은 본문 내용과 일치한다. 정부가 만든 화폐의 문제점은 정부 관리자들이 더 많은 돈을 만들고 사용하려는 유혹에 직면한다는 점이며, 고대 왕부터 현대 정치인까지 이런 일이 반복되어 인플레이션을 초래했다. 많은 국가들이 공급이 제한된 금, 은 등의 물질을 화폐로 사용했으며, 금은 공급량을 빠르게 늘릴 수 없어 이상적인 재료로 간주되었다. 이러한 방식은 정부가 화폐 공급을 인플레이션 수준으로 확대하는 권한을 제한하기 위한 것이다.
